	           if (!url) {
	                 return {};
	           }
	            url.replace(/([^?=&amp;]+)(=([^&amp;]*))?/g, function ($0, $1, $2, $3) { q[$1] = $3; });

  <link href="http://www.extremetech.com/wp-includes/wlwmanifest.xml" rel="wlwmanifest" type="application/wlwmanifest+xml"/>
  <link href="http://www.extremetech.com/gaming/165674-xbox-one-release-date-confirmed-for-november-22-a-week-after-the-ps4" rel="prev" title="Xbox One release date confirmed for November 22, a week after the PS4"/>
  <link href="http://www.extremetech.com/deals/165708-et-deals-dell-xps-15-laptop-with-16gb-ram-512gb-ssd-blu-ray-for-1800" rel="next" title="ET deals: Dell XPS 15 laptop with 16GB RAM, 512GB SSD, Blu-ray for $1800"/>

         <style type="text/css">
          #stickybanner,

           <a href="http://pubads.g.doubleclick.net/gampad/jump?iu=/4585/zd.extech/electronicssection_ATF&amp;t=zdid%3D165675%26cmn%3Dzd&amp;sz=970x250|728x90&amp;template=article_sticky&amp;c=8918769&amp;tile=1">

     <div id="main">
      <div class="add-nav">
       <ul class="breadcrumbs" id="breadcrumbs">
        <!-- Breadcrumb NavXT 5.1.1 -->
        <li class="home">
         <a href="http://www.extremetech.com" title="Go to ExtremeTech.">
          ExtremeTech
         </a>
        </li>
        <li>
         <span typeof="v:Breadcrumb">
          <a class="taxonomy category" href="http://www.extremetech.com/category/electronics" property="v:title" rel="v:url" title="Go to the Electronics category archives.">
           Electronics
          </a>
         </span>

        <li class="current_item">
         Sony QX lens-style cameras for your smartphone: Is this the future of point-and-shoots?
        </li>
       </ul>
      </div>
      <div class="twocolumns">
       <div id="content">
        <div class="article">
         <div class="title">
          <h2>
           Sony QX lens-style cameras for your smartphone: Is this the future of point-and-shoots?
          </h2>
          <ul>
           <li>
            <span class="by vcard">
             By
             <a href="http://www.extremetech.com/author/dcardinal" rel="author" title="Posts by David Cardinal">
              David Cardinal
             </a>
             on September 4, 2013 at 3:03 pm
            </span>
           </li>
           <li class="comments">
            <a data-disqus-identifier="165675 http://www.extremetech.com/?p=165675" href="http://www.extremetech.com/electronics/165675-sony-launches-qx-lens-style-cameras-for-your-smartphone-is-this-the-future-of-point-and-shoots#disqus_thread">
             <span>
              Comment
             </span>
            </a>
           </li>
          </ul>
         </div>
         <div class="content">
          <span id="intelliTXT" name="intellitxt">
           <img alt="Sony Cyber-shot DSC-QX100 Lens-style Camera" class="attachment-full wp-post-image" height="353" src="http://www.extremetech.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/09/Sony-Cyber-shot-DSC-QX100-Lens-style-Camera-640x353.jpg" width="640"/>
           <div class="photo">
            <div class="box2">
             <h3>
              Share This article
             </h3>
             <div class="addthis_sharing_toolbox">
             </div>
            </div>
           </div>
           <p>
            Its no secret that the conventional point-and-shoot camera is dying a slow death  killed by the convenience and increasing quality of smartphone cameras. Standalone camera vendors have fought back with feature-filled models and phone/camera hybrids, but havent found a compelling way to combine those capabilities with the smartphone form factor. Sonys new DSC-QX100 and DSC-QX10, announced at IFA 2013, embody a novel approach to the problem. They are WiFi-enabled lens-style cameras with minimal controls, designed to be attached to, and operated by, a smartphone. In short, they are complete cameras, but without a body or screen.
           </p>
           <h3>
            Sony DSC-QX100: DSLR-quality images with smartphone handling
           </h3>
           <p>
            There is no question Sony makes great camera technology. For the $500 list price of the QX100 (pictured below) you get what Sony calls a DSLR-quality 1-inch, 20.2MP sensor, along with all the fancy electronics youd expect in a similarly priced mirrorless or an expensive point-and-shoot. In fact its sensor is identical to the one found in the
            <a href="http://www.pcmag.com/article2/0,2817,2422759,00.asp">
             highly-rated Sony DSC-RX100v2
            </a>
            , a $649 point-and-shoot often touted as being competitive with DSLRs when it comes to image quality.
           </p>
           <p>
            The camera itself is dwarfed by its Zeiss f/1.8 3.6x zoom lens, which should provide images that are far better than any smartphone. Another unique feature is that the QX100 features a control ring like some high-end point-and-shoots, a welcome alternative for serious photographers to having to change all the settings from an LCD screen. Its shooting modes and other functions are very similar to those found on similarly priced point-and-shoots  except that they are controlled using an application on the phone instead of from the camera itself. A big open question will be how fast the camera-plus-lens combination can react, and therefore how effective it will be for capturing action compared to a dedicated camera.
           </p>
           <h3>
            Sony DSC-QX10: Finally a superzoom for smartphones
           </h3>
           <p>
            <a href="http://www.extremetech.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/09/Sony-Cyber-shot-QX100-f1.8-Zeiss-Lens.jpg">
             <img alt="Sony Cyber-shot QX100 f1.8 Zeiss Lens" class="alignright size-medium wp-image-165712" height="225" src="http://www.extremetech.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/09/Sony-Cyber-shot-QX100-f1.8-Zeiss-Lens-300x225.jpg" width="300"/>
            </a>
            The much-less-expensive, $250 list price, Sony DSC-QX10 (pictured above) is aimed squarely at the Achilles heel of smartphones  zoom. As high-resolution as smartphones have gotten,
            <a href="http://www.extremetech.com/computing/161117-nokia-lumia-1020-41-glorious-megapixels-of-back-illuminated-image-stabilized-magic">
             digitally cropping their images
            </a>
            to achieve large zoom ratios is at best a poor solution. By offering a 10x zoom lens and its own 18.2MP Exmor sensor, this accessory turns just about any smartphone into an all-in-one travel camera. Weighing less than four ounces, Id expect this to be a very popular holiday purchase for anyone looking to beef up their phone photography without carrying around a second camera.
           </p>
           <h3>
            Using a QX lens-style camera with your phone
           </h3>
           <p>
            The QX models are designed to physically clip onto the back of your smartphone. If your phone is NFC-enabled, proximity should be enough to pair it for operation over WiFi. If not youll need to set it up manually. Other than the automatic pairing and keeping the lens and phone physically together, the mount doesnt provide any other functionality, so you could have the QX in a separate location within WiFi range and use your phone as a remote control. In fact the QX models actually have their own basic controls and a memory card slot, so they can be used as standalone cameras in a pinch.
           </p>
           <h3>
            Smartphone magic with your camera images
           </h3>
           <p>
            Because the QX models are so tightly integrated with your phone, Sonys free PlayMemories app can be used to completely control the camera settings, as well as to manage, edit and share your images. Short-term this is a good thing, as the app has plenty of bells and whistles. Longer term itll be interesting to see whether the QX models can be controlled by third-party camera applications the way existing smartphone cameras can. Otherwise youll wind up needing to use your phone camera from two different interfaces depending on whether you have the QX enabled.
           </p>
           <p>
            Sony expects both QX models to be available late in September, along with an optional case and a camera case attachment customized for use with Sony Xperia phones. Remember that because the QX models are actually standalone cameras, they also have their own batteries which will need recharging.
           </p>
           <p>
            The newness of Sonys design is obvious right from its product description. Referring to the new models as lens-style cameras (complete with quotes) shows that these devices dont have a product category yet. If the physical connectivity doesnt prove to be too awkward, and the WiFi connectivity is reliable and quick enough to capture action scenes, expect these to be only the first of many lens-style cameras for your smartphone.
           </p>
          </span>
         </div>
         <div class="articles-list">
          <div class="holder">
           <div class="widget column widget_execphp" id="execphp-45">
            <div data-page-type="article" data-placement="Below Article Thumbnails - Article -gtd" id="taboola-below-article-thumbnails">
            </div>
            <script type="text/javascript">
             window._taboola = window._taboola || [];
      _taboola.push({
        mode: 'thumbnails-a',
        container: 'taboola-below-article-thumbnails',
        placement: 'Below Article Thumbnails - Article -gtd',
        target_type: 'mix'
      });
            </script>
            <div data-page-type="article" data-placement="Below Article Text Links - Article -gtd" id="taboola-below-article-text-links">
            </div>
            <script type="text/javascript">
             window._taboola = window._taboola || [];
      _taboola.push({
        mode: 'hybrid-text-links-a',

        target_type: 'mix'
      });
            </script>
           </div>
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="articles-list">
         <div class="holder">

           </div>
          </div>
          <div class="widget column widget_disquswidget" id="disquswidget-3">
           <script type="text/javascript">
            var disqus_developer = 1;
           </script>
           <div class="title">
            <span class="count">
             <a href="#disqus_thread">
              Comment
             </a>
            </span>
            <h3>
             Post a Comment
            </h3>
           </div>
           <div id="disqus_thread">
            <div id="dsq-content">
             <ul id="dsq-comments">
              <li class="comment even thread-even depth-1" id="dsq-comment-199936">
               <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-199936">
                <cite id="dsq-cite-199936">
                 <span id="dsq-author-user-199936">
                  Datamisc
                 </span>
                </cite>
               </div>
               <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-199936">
                <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-199936">
                 <p>
                  No, in my opinion its not the future. Just get a Lumia 1020 with 41mp camera, take the picture zoom later. That thing must be either being on the camera or you risk to loose the moment, and the first option just makes it too bulky.
                 </p>
                </div>
               </div>
               <ul class="children">
                <li class="comment odd alt depth-2" id="dsq-comment-199999">
                 <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-199999">
                  <cite id="dsq-cite-199999">
                   http://www.cardinalphoto.com
                   <span id="dsq-author-user-199999">
                    David Cardinal
                   </span>
                  </cite>
                 </div>
                 <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-199999">
                  <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-199999">
                   <p>
                    Thats certainly my fear (the klunkiness of dealing with separate components). OTOH, having a really awesome sensor on a smallish lens that I could hold over my head, put on a tripod, or clip to my smartphone is strangely attractive.
                   </p>
                   <p>
                    I wonder if there is a market for some type of transformer device that would clip together  nicely, not just with a clamp  to make a really good camera, or come apart to be used as just a smartphone with a regular camera?
                   </p>
                  </div>
                 </div>
                </li>
                <!-- #comment-## -->
                <li class="comment even depth-2" id="dsq-comment-200101">

                   </p>
                  </div>

               <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-200161">
                <cite id="dsq-cite-200161">
                 <span id="dsq-author-user-200161">
                  ronch
                 </span>
                </cite>
               </div>
               <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-200161">
                <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-200161">
                 <p>
                  This is an ingenious innovation from Sony. It doesnt surprise me to see that Sony is the one who thought of doing this first (AFAIK) because Sony has BOTH smartphone technology AND *proper* DSLR know-how (Samsung also has cameras, but). Nobody can say if its gonna convert die-hard DSLR experts over to this technology or not, nor can anybody say if its gonna be the future of cameras, but who knows, right? If this approach of literally just splitting the DSLR into the lens/sensor modules and the rest (controls, screen, etc.) and just connecting them wirelessly results in the same convenience and image quality as DSLRs today, it may very well replace DSLR-only devices the same way smartphones have literally made MP3 players obsolete. Companies also have a tendency to copy what looks cool out there and before you know it, the market is flooded with copycats or similar stuff. Smartphone makers such as Motorola or LG obviously dont have DSLR tech, so they will have to partner up with DSLR makers such as Olympus and Nikon to pull off something like this. As for Apple, perhaps theyll acquire a camera company and use their tech as their own rather than allowing said company to hitch a ride on their strong brand image (which is on the decline, anyway).
                 </p>
                 <p>
                  The main thing here is that Sony is creating a new gimmick, if you will, that makes people feel like theyre using a true DSLR alternative without buying a real DSLR, and simply snap it on as an upgrade to their smartphones. Its quite a novel idea, actually. I like it. The only concerns I have have to do with privacy (because the lens module is literally broadcasting your photos.. there must be some strong encryption built-in), and power, because the lens module will obviously need its own power source, as the article has mentioned.
                 </p>
                </div>
               </div>
              </li>
              <!-- #comment-## -->
              <li class="comment odd alt thread-odd thread-alt depth-1" id="dsq-comment-208353">
               <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-208353">
                <cite id="dsq-cite-208353">
                 <span id="dsq-author-user-208353">
                  Jacob Wadsworth
                 </span>
                </cite>
               </div>
               <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-208353">
                <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-208353">
                 <p>
                  I have seen what the latest model of Xperia can do in terms of its camera quality and it has amazed me. The image is so vivid and it can shoot in any condition always giving the best quality photo. So much so if a lens like that is being attached. You dont have to bring anymore your bulky DSLRs. 
                  <a href="http://www.lensgiant.com/" rel="nofollow">
                   http://www.lensgiant.com/
                  </a>
                 </p>
                </div>
               </div>
              </li>
              <!-- #comment-## -->
             </ul>
            </div>
           </div>
           <script type="text/javascript">
            /* &lt;![CDATA[ */

        var config = this; // Access to the config object
        config.language = '';

        /*
           All currently supported events:
            * preData  fires just before we request for initial data
            * preInit - fires after we get initial data but before we load any dependencies
            * onInit  - fires when all dependencies are resolved but before dtpl template is rendered
            * afterRender - fires when template is rendered but before we show it
            * onReady - everything is done
         */

        config.callbacks.preData.push(function() {
            // clear out the container (its filled for SEO/legacy purposes)
            document.getElementById(disqus_container_id).innerHTML = '';
        });
                config.callbacks.onReady.push(function() {
            // sync comments in the background so we don't block the page
            var script = document.createElement('script');
            script.async = true;
            script.src = '?cf_action=sync_comments&amp;post_id=165675';

            var firstScript = document.getElementsByTagName( "script" )[0];
            firstScript.parentNode.insertBefore(script, firstScript);
        });
                    };
/* ]]&gt; */
           </script>

       <div class="widget column widget_execphp" id="execphp-46">
        <script type="text/javascript">
         window._taboola = window._taboola || [];
    _taboola.push({flush: true});
    
    var __ZDTABEVENT = {
        accountid : "",
        init : function(acct) {
            __ZDTABEVENT.accountid = acct;
            var divs = document.querySelectorAll("div[id^=taboola]"), i=divs.length;
            while (i--) {
                divs[i].addEventListener("click", __ZDTABEVENT.clkevt);
                __ZDTABEVENT.track(divs[i].id, "imp");
            }
        },
        clkevt : function(evt){
            __ZDTABEVENT.track(evt.currentTarget.id, "clk");


        },
        track : function(id,evt) {
            var el = document.getElementById(id);
            var placement = el.getAttribute('data-placement');
            var pagetype = el.getAttribute('data-page-type');
            if(window.ga) window.ga('send', 'event', 'Taboola', pagetype + '-' + placement, evt);
            if(window._gaq) window._gaq.push(['_trackEvent', 'Taboola', pagetype+'-'+placement, evt, undefined, true]);
            if (__ZDDMP) { __ZDDMP.Event({signal:'taboola', pubid: __ZDTABEVENT.accountid, ptype:pagetype, placement:placement, evt:evt});}
        }
    };
    __ZDTABEVENT.init('ziffdavis-network15-extremetech');
        </script>
       </div>

    nstrack.src = "http://track.netshelter.net/async/js/sites/extremetech.com-async.js";

        </div>
        <script>
         (function(s, p, d) {
  var h=d.location.protocol, i=p+"-"+s,
      e=d.getElementById(i), r=d.getElementById(p+"-root"),
      u=h==="https:"?"d1z2jf7jlzjs58.cloudfront.net"
      :"static."+p+".com";
  if (e) return;
  e = d.createElement(s); e.id = i; e.async = true;

       <div class="widget column widget_execphp" id="execphp-17">
        <!-- Vibrant Ads -->
        <script type="text/javascript">
         if (ZDXI.IsIntl()) {
	document.write('&lt;scr'+'ipt type="text/javascript" src="http://extremetech.us.intellitxt.com/intellitxt/front.asp?ipid=5281"&gt;&lt;/scr'+'ipt&gt;');

       <div class="widget column widget_execphp" id="execphp-26">
        <!-- chartbeat -->
        <script type="text/javascript">
         var _sf_async_config = _sf_async_config || {};
/** CONFIGURATION START **/
&lt;!-- set in head --&gt;
_sf_async_config.sections = 'Electronics'; 
_sf_async_config.authors ='David Cardinal';
/** CONFIGURATION END **/
(function(){
function loadChartbeat()
{ window._sf_endpt=(new Date()).getTime(); var e = document.createElement('script'); e.setAttribute('language', 'javascript'); e.setAttribute('type', 'text/javascript'); e.setAttribute('src', '//static.chartbeat.com/js/chartbeat.js'); document.body.appendChild(e); }

var oldonload = window.onload;
window.onload = (typeof window.onload != 'function') ?
loadChartbeat : function()
{ oldonload(); loadChartbeat(); }

;
})();
        </script>
       </div>
       <div class="widget column widget_execphp" id="execphp-23">
        <!-- Begin BlueKai Tag -->
        <iframe frameborder="0" height="0" name="__bkframe" src="javascript:void(0)" width="0">
        </iframe>
        <script src="http://tags.bkrtx.com/js/bk-coretag.js" type="text/javascript">
        </script>
        <script type="text/javascript">
         (function() {
  var segments = __ZDDMP.GetPSegs();
    for (var i = 0; i &lt; segments.length; i++) {
         bk_addPageCtx("bbseg", segments[i]);
    }
    bk_doJSTag(20188, 10);
}) ();
        </script>
        <!-- End BlueKai Tag -->
       </div>
       <div class="widget column widget_execphp" id="execphp-33">
        <div id="adsense" style="visibility:hidden; position:absolute;">
         unused
        </div>
        <script type="text/javascript">
         jQuery(document).ready(function() {
  setTimeout(function() {
  if (jQuery("#adsense").height() &lt; 8) { 
    if (window._gaq) { window._gaq.push(['_trackEvent', 'AdBlocker','Blocked' ,undefined, undefined, true]); }
    if (window.ga) { window.ga('send', 'event', 'AdBlocker', 'Blocked'); }
  } else {
    if (window._gaq) { window._gaq.push(['_trackEvent', 'AdBlocker','NotBlocked' ,undefined, undefined, true]); }
    if (window.ga) { window.ga('send', 'event', 'AdBlocker', 'NotBlocked' ); }
    }
	}, 2000);
});
        </script>
       </div>

  <!-- This website is patched against a big problem not solved from WordPress 2.5+ to date -->
  <script type="text/javascript">
   // &lt;![CDATA[
        var disqus_shortname = 'extremetech';
        (function () {
            var nodes = document.getElementsByTagName('span');
            for (var i = 0, url; i &lt; nodes.length; i++) {
                if (nodes[i].className.indexOf('dsq-postid') != -1) {
                    nodes[i].parentNode.setAttribute('data-disqus-identifier', nodes[i].getAttribute('rel'));
                    url = nodes[i].parentNode.href.split('#', 1);
                    if (url.length == 1) url = url[0];
                    else url = url[1]
                    nodes[i].parentNode.href = url + '#disqus_thread';
                }
            }
            var s = document.createElement('script'); s.async = true;
            s.type = 'text/javascript';
            s.src = '//' + 'disqus.com/forums/' + disqus_shortname + '/count.js';
            (document.getElementsByTagName('HEAD')[0] || document.getElementsByTagName('BODY')[0]).appendChild(s);
        }());
    //]]&gt;
  </script>
